content.description: Climb Wet Wanny to the 4th bolt, traverse left of the bulge, then head up and slightly left climbing past 2 more bolts to 2 bolt anchor.

Hop across rocks to left side of Guadalupe Rock and traverse right all the way to the farthest white streak (to the right of right face). Clip bolt down low before difficult moves onto route. First bolt is to prevent you from falling in the water. Clip second bolt and head straight up.   When lowering off, I recommend to clip long sling to the boulder in the shade so you can swing out and grab it to pull yourself in.  Requires good teamwork to avoid getting wet!  If TRing, it’s best to lead Tsunami Queaky to chains and belay from creek near trail.
content.protection: 5 bolts to two bolt anchor.  Follow bolt line over right side of bulge and head for chains on right side of rock.
content.location: Farthest white streak on the right.

content.description: This route follows the other white streak to the right of Wet Wanny.  Hop the rocks on the far left side and traverse in all the way from the left side of the rock.  Clip the first two bolts of Wet Wanny, then traverse down and right, then head straight up the series of mini roofs passing 3 more bolts to Wet Wanny chains.  Bolt is on boulder to keep belayer from falling in.  When lowering off, I recommend to clip long sling to the boulder in the shade so you can swing out and grab it to pull yourself in.  Requires good teamwork to avoid getting wet!  If TRing, it’s best to lead Tsunami Queaky to chains and belay from creek near trail.
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.  First 2 bolts shared with Wet Wanny.
content.location: To the right of Wet Wanny

content.description: Begin route by starting on the right side, near the trail, and following the black streak up.  Go left at 3rd bolt to reach Wet Wanny anchors.  When lowering off, I recommend to clip long sling to the boulder in the shade so you can swing out and grab it to pull yourself in.  If TRing, it’s best to lead Tsunami Queaky to chains and belay from creek near trail.
content.location: Southeast side of rock.  Farthest route to the right.

content.description: The lower half of the route is covered in a thin layer of dirt, the upper half lichen.
content.protection: As of this post, there are bolts on the face for this route. Shiny, new-looking, no rust.
content.location: Traverse about 5-6 feet right of the Right Crack then follow the face straight up, eventually merging with the crack when you hit the slabby section near the top. Belay from the opposite shore, there is a bolt to clip the belayer too.

content.description: This is a rather awkward climb if you're not used to the rock. Once figured out the 5.9 grade seems a bit more likely. The route follows a shallow crack that could probably be lead with some crafty gear placements.
content.protection: Several bolts on top make this an easy TR option.
content.location: Visible in the beta photo this route follows the diagonal crack on the right side of the main face.

content.description: Just to the left of Tidal Wave.  Better climb IMO.  Making the moves up to the second bolt is the most difficult part of the climb.  Reach high over the bulge to get a descent hold.
content.location: Hop the rocks as per usual.  Climb right a little bit then straight up.  The route follows the bolt line between left crack and tidal wave.

content.description: This route follows the left crack on the front of the rock.  The start is right over water, so you'll have to lower down to the very bottom unless you want to wade the stream (which may or may not be legal).  The route is very sustained throughout (I was getting surprisingly pumped) and there are a bunch of fun crack and face moves to keep you entertained the whole time, plus a fun little mantle in the middle to mix things up.
content.protection: Two bolts at the top for anchors (bring long slings and webbing to set up).  There are a couple rusted 1/4 inch bolts on the route that should not be trusted.  If they were replaced this might be able to be lead
content.location: This route uses the Tidal Wave anchors and is located just to the left of Tidal Wave (see topo)

content.description: Start standing on a rock in front of the 5.3 route or on the far left side of the rock and traverse right to the right most route on the boulder and step off or traverse the rest of the rock. I haven't traversed the entire rock yet because I don't want to go swimming but I would guess it's at least a V5/6 and a first ascent. Good summertime activity.
content.protection: Water/mud/rocks depending on where you fall and the water level you might get your shoes wet or you might be swimming.
content.location: Cross the stream and stand on the left most boulder sticking out of the water or start on the very left side of the rock by a smaller boulder that has a low quality boulder problem

content.description: An easy gully with a light coating of moss due to light use. This would be a good route for a first-time to get them feeling confident.
content.protection: There is one bolt that can be clipped and some gear could be placed if needed.
content.location: This route follows the obvious low grade 5 "gully" on the far left side of the face.

content.description:
If you're looking for a route to have someone do their first lead, this is it. Tight bolt spacing for timid leaders, easy moves generally with lots of hand and foothold options, and you can wander left or right and it's still easy. All clipping stances are secure.

Uncertain of the grade as it's a bit hard to say when it's this easy. But it's easy. Also a good option to top rope for a complete newbie and has easier rope management then the routes above the creek.
content.protection: 8 bolts to clip in anchors. For top roping the anchors for Far Left Face can be used, in which case it would be wise to extend the master point over the edge of the rock as they are a couple feet back.
content.location: On the left side of Guadalupe Rock just right of the big L that's part of the "S + L" chiseled into the rock.

content.description: This route is named Bolt Line in the new Bay Area Rock book. Good holds on slightly-less-than-vertical rock makes for a sustained but easy climb.
content.protection: 4 Bolts lead to two bolt clip-in anchor.
content.location: This route follows the face just left of Left Crack and is shown in the  beta photo.

content.description: To TR, easiest to lead Tsunami Queaky up to chains.  Have belayer lower you to water and climb up.   Belay from creek near the trail (far right side).
content.location: Between Underwater Papa and Taunami Queaky.
